message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about how animals regulate their body temperature. When a horse is in a field under the summer sun, it can become hot and start to sweat to cool off. Option (B) is the correct answer because sweat glands release liquid to cool off the horse through evaporation. Option (A) is incorrect because other horses licking the wet horse would not explain why it was glistening wet. Option (C) is also incorrect because if the sweat glands dried up, the horse would not be wet. Option (D) is unrelated to the process of the horse sweating to cool off.

This question requires basic knowledge about how horses regulate their body temperature. When a horse is in a field under the summer sun, it may become glistening wet due to sweat. Horses have sweat glands that release liquid to cool off their bodies. Option (A) is incorrect because horses do not lick each other to cool off. Option (C) is incorrect because sweat glands continue to function unless there is a medical issue. Option (D) is unlikely because horses do not need showers like humans and do not naturally become oily.

This question requires knowledge about how horses cool themselves off in hot weather. Horses do not have sweat glands all over their bodies like humans do. Instead, they have specialized sweat glands that release liquid to cool them off. When a horse is in a field under the summer sun, it may appear glistening wet because its sweat glands have released liquid to cool off its body. Option (A) is incorrect because horses do not cool themselves by other horses licking them. Option (C) is incorrect because if the sweat glands dried up, the horse would not be wet. Option (D) is incorrect because the wetness is due to sweat, not oil.
